conclusion: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time: a = dv/dt.
On a velocity-time graph, the acceleration at any point is represented by the slope of the curve at that point.
At time t1, the velocity of Object A is decreasing, and its curve is sloping downward.
At time t1, the velocity of Object B is increasing, and its curve is sloping upward.

premise: At time t1, the velocity of Object A is decreasing, and its curve is sloping downward.
conclusion: Object A has a negative acceleration at t1.

premise: At time t1, the velocity of Object B is increasing, and its curve is sloping upward.
conclusion: Object B has a positive acceleration at t1.

premise: Object A has a negative acceleration at t1. Object B has a positive acceleration at t1.
conclusion: The accelerations of Object A and Object B at t1 are not the same because one is negative and the other is positive.

premise: The accelerations of Object A and Object B at t1 are not the same because one is negative and the other is positive.
conclusion: No, Object A and Object B do not have the same acceleration at time t1.
